I'd like to first focus on these two things, since you clearly do not understand how rights work:
Free speech means you have the right to voice your opinion. Apart from the fact that even free speech has limits, this right **only** guarantees you that the **government** won't punish you for voicing your opinion. If Riot somehow got the real life police to arrest you for something you said, **then** you could cite free speech.
And playing the game? That's not even a right to begin with. You don't have a right to a private company providing a service to you.

And in all honesty, this is by far the biggest source of problems with online toxicity. It always comes down to the same thing: entitlement.
You are neither entitled to playing this game nor are you entitled to Riot giving you a platform for your "free speech".

As for the rest of your points:

Most people don't "choose" being offended by things. If you can consciously choose your own emotions, cool, but most people can't.

Mute is an after-the-fact band-aid fix that only serves to mitigate the effect of flaming. It neither fixes the actual problem, nor can it prevent it unless people sacrifice the social aspect of the game completely by preemptively muting everybody.
Muting is a workaround, not a solution.

"It's not sexist, racist or homophobic" does not mean "it's good". In fact, using this as a way to relativize something makes it sound pretty bad.
I mean... if you heard somebody closing a story with "Well, at least Steve is in a stable condition" you wouldn't exactly assume the story was about how Steve won the lottery.

And as for the "misleading" statement on negativity:
Nobody here has said that there exists a negative statement that is acceptable (even though there probably are many that by themselves will not be persecuted).
What The Djinn said was to use **less** negative statements. Right off the bat: That includes positive statements. Positive is less negative.
The system does, however, also differentiate between different levels of negativity, so something **less** negative is absolutely **more** acceptable and **less** punishable.
Saying "gg ez" is less negative than "you're a fucking idiot", which in turn is less negative than "I hope you die in a fire".

That' fair enough... but I'm not attacking your opinion, I'm attacking the arguments that you brought up to support it.
Case in point:

> I don't agree with assigning criminality to words even if their intolerant, ignorant or spiteful.

Which is absolutely not what is happening here. Riot isn't assigning criminality to words... that would **actually** infringe your freedom of speech.
What they are doing is exerting **their** rights, by reacting to what you said and imposing consequences without infringing any of your rights.

At the end of the day that's the issue with your free speech argument:
You act as if you value personal freedom... but you really only value **your** personal freedom, while trying to use it as an argument against Riot's freedom.

So once again: I'm not attacking your opinion that Riot isn't dealing with this matter appropriately (although I do disagree with it), but your argument. And the truth is that any argument that is based on your rights is perfectly countered by an argument based on Riot's rights.

It's legal for you to flame people on Riot's servers. It's legal for Riot to ban you as a reaction.
Nobody's rights are being infringed in this situation. So there's absolutely no reason to bring up rights.
